title-group.article-title: Neutrophil to Lymphocyte Ratio Is Associated With the Severity of Coronary Artery Disease in Patients With ST-Segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Cardiology, Adana Numune Education and Research Hospital, Adana, Turkey
2Department of Cardiology, School of Medicine, Harran University, Şanlıurfa, Turkey
3Department of Cardiology, Private Metropark Hospital, Adana, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Durmuş Yıldıray Şahin, Department of Cardiology, Adana Numune Education and Research Hospital, Adana 01170, Turkey. Email: dysahin79@hotmail.com

abstract.p: We assessed the relationship between the severity of coronary artery disease assessed by SYNTAX score (SS) and neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio (N:L ratio) in patients with ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). In total, 840 patients with STEMI in whom primary percutaneous coronary intervention was performed were prospectively included (622 male, 218 female; mean age 58.6 ± 12.4 years). Total and differential leukocyte counts and other biochemical markers were measured at admission. Patients were categorized into tertiles on the basis of SS. The N:L ratio of SShigh group was higher compared with SSlow and SSmid groups (P < .001 for all). Multivariate regression analysis showed that N:L ratio (β = .277, P < .001), ejection fraction (β = −.086, P = .012), age (β = .104, P = .004), and diabetes (β = .152, P < .001) were the independent predictors for SS in patients with STEMI.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Inflammation plays a pivotal role in the progression of atherosclerosis. 1,2 White blood cell (WBC) count and the neutrophil and lymphocyte have been investigated as inflammatory markers to predict cardiovascular outcomes in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD). 3
–7 High neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio (N:L ratio) was reported to be associated with increased cardiac mortality in clinically stable patients with CAD. 6,7 Increased N:L ratio was also reported to be associated with the presence and long-term mortality of ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). 8

The SYNTAX score (SS) is an angiographic lesion-based scoring system originally invented to evaluate the complexity of CAD. 9 It is able to aid revascularization decisions and predicts mortality and morbidity in patients with CAD. 9
–14

Although predictive value of N:L ratio in patients with stable CAD and STEMI is well known, the relationship between N:L ratio and the severity of CAD in patients with STEMI has not been clearly determined.
In this study, we aimed to assess relationship between the severity of coronary atherosclerosis assessed by SS and N:L ratio in patients with STEMI.

sec.title: Study Population
sec.p: In this study, 840 patients with STEMI in whom primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) was performed in our cardiology clinic between January 2011 and March 2012 were included (622 male, 218 female; mean age 58.6 ± 12.4 years). To achieve homogeneous distribution, patients were categorized into tertiles on the basis of SS. Those with a history of acute myocardial infarction (AMI), PCI, coronary artery bypass graft, infectious or inflammatory disease, severe liver or renal disease, neoplasm, or hematological disorders were excluded from our study. The STEMI was defined based on the criteria formulated by the American College of Cardiology and the European Society of Cardiology 15 : an increase in troponin I >1 ng/mL with a new ST elevation was measured from the J point in ≥2 contiguous leads with at least 0.2 mV in leads V1, V2, and V3, or at least 0.1 mV in the remaining leads during the first 12 hours after the onset of symptoms.

Baseline characteristics of patients with STEMI were recorded, such as age, gender, body mass index, history of hyperlipidemia, smoker at admission, history of hypertension (HT), history of diabetes mellitus (DM), family history, medications, systolic blood pressure (SBP), diastolic blood pressure (DBP) and heart rate (beats/min). Ejection fraction (EF) was determined using Simpson method, according to the suggestions of the American Society of Echocardiography. 16 The study was performed according to the recommendations of Declaration of Helsinki on Biomedical Research Involving Human Subjects. The institutional ethics committee approved the study protocol, and each participant provided written informed consent.

sec.title: Blood Samples
sec.p: Samples of peripheral venous blood were drawn from antecubital vein at admission. Blood counts were measured by a Sysmex K-1000 (Block Scientific, Bohemia, New York) autoanalyzer within 5 minutes of sampling. Plasma triglyceride, low-density lipoprotein (LDL), high-density lipoprotein (HDL), glucose, uric acid (UA), and creatinine concentrations were measured with an automated chemistry analyzer (Abbott Aeroset, Minnesota, USA) using commercial kits (Abbott). Activity of creatine kinase MB (CK-MB) was measured with an assay that uses 2 monoclonal antibodies (CKMB STAT) on an Elecsys 2010 analyzer (Roche Diagnostics, Basel, Switzerland) by electrochemiluminescence immunoassay.

sec.title: SYNTAX Score and Angiographic Analysis
sec.p: All patients underwent selective coronary angiography using the Judkins technique. Coronary lesions leading to ≥50% diameter stenosis in vessels ≥1.5 mm was scored separately and added together to provide the cumulative SS which was prospectively calculated using the SS algorithm on the baseline diagnostic angiogram. 9,17 Two experienced interventional cardiologists analyzed the SS; the opinion of a third analyst was obtained and the final judgment was made by consensus in cases of disagreement. The final score was calculated from the individual lesion scores by analysts who were blinded to procedural data and clinical outcome.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
Baseline Characteristics
sec.p: The mean SS was 15.1 ± 7. The SS classified as tertiles are SSlow ≤11 (n = 259), SSmid >11 and ≤18 (n = 283), and SShigh >18 (n = 298). Our data were collected from patients with 422 (50.2%) anterior STEMI, 351 (41.8%) inferior STEMI, 56 (6.7%) posterior and infero-right ventricle STEMI, and 11 (1.3%) high lateral STEMI (Table 1).

fn.p: Abbreviations: MI, myocardial infarction; Post. and RV; posterior and right ventricle.

sec.p: Baseline demographic, echocardiographic, laboratory, and hemodynamic variables of patient groups were compared in Table 2. Mean age of SShigh group was higher than SSlow and SSmid groups (P < .05 for all). Frequency of HT, smoking, hyperlipidemia, and positive family history were similar between the groups (P > .05 for all). Frequency of DM was different between patient groups (P < .005 for all). Triglyceride, LDL, and HDL-cholesterol levels were similar between groups (P > .05 for all). The WBC count of SShigh group was higher compared with SSlow and SSmid groups (P = .042 and P = .018, respectively). The N:L ratio of SShigh group was higher compared with SSlow and SSmid groups (P < .001 for all). When SS was increased, both platelet (P = .136) and eosinophil counts (P = .112) were tended to decrease. Uric acid and creatinine levels of SShigh group were higher than SSlow group (P = .002 and P < .001, respectively) and SSmid groups (P < .001 and P = .003, respectively). Troponin and CK-MB levels of SShigh group were higher than in SSlow group (P = .001 and P = .001, respectively). The CK-MB activity of SShigh group was higher than that of SSmid group (P = .018).

fn.p: Abbreviations: ACE, angiotensin converting enzyme; ARB, angiotensin receptor blocker; BMI, body mass index; DBP, diastolic blood pressure; N:L ratio, neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio; SBP, systolic blood pressure; WBC, white blood cell count; PLT, platelets; LDL, low-density lipoprotein; HSL, high-density lipoprotein; CK-MB, creatine kinase MB.
a P = .01 versus SSmid and P < .001 versus SShigh.
b P = .007 versus SShigh.
c Chi-square test.
d P = .009 versus SSlow and P = .028 versus SSmid.
e P = .001 versus SSlow and P = .014 versus SSmid.
f P < .001 versus SSlow and SSmid.

h P < .001 versus SSlow and SSmid.
i P = .001 versus SSmid and P < .001 versus SShigh.
j P < .001 versus SShigh.
k P = .007 versus SSmid, and P < .001 versus SShigh.
l P < .001 versus SShigh.
m P < .001 versus SSlow and P = .002 versus SSmid.
n P = .003 versus SSmid and P < .001 versus SSlow.
o P = .001 versus SSlow and P = .018 versus SSmid.
p P = .007 versus SSmid and P = .001 versus SShigh.

sec.title: Predictors of SS
sec.p: Bivariate and multivariate relationships of the SS values in groups were reported in Table 3. SYNTAX score was correlated with age (P < .001), presence of DM (P < .001), EF (P < .001), presence of dyslipidemia (P = .04), SBP (P = .020), DBP (P = .026), heart rate (P < .001), LDL-cholesterol (P = .043), statin use (P = .04), antidiabetic use (P < .001), UA (P < .001), creatinine (P < .001), CK-MB (P = .001), troponin (P = .005), WBC (P = .031), and N:L ratio (P < .001) in bivariate analysis. Multivariate regression analysis showed that N:L ratio (β = .277, P < .001), EF (β = −.086, P = .012), age (β = .104, P = .004), and presence of DM (β = .152, P < .001) were the independent predictors for SS (usage of statins and antidiabetics were not included in multivariate analysis since the presence of hyperlipidemia and DM are included in the analysis). Relationship between N:L ratio and SS was demonstrated in Figure 1.

caption.p: Scatter graph showing strong correlation between SYNTAX score and neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio.
Bivariate and Multivariate Relationships of the SS in Patient Group (n = 840).

fn.p: Abbreviations: ACE, angiotensin converting enzyme; ARB, angiotensin receptor blocker; BMI, body mass index; DBP, diastolic blood pressure; DM, diabetes mellitus; EF, ejection fraction; F, female; HT, hypertension; M, male; N:L ratio, neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio; SBP, systolic blood pressure; WBC, white blood cell count; LDL, low-density lipoprotein; HSL, high-density lipoprotein; CK-MB, creatine kinase MB.
a From multiple linear regression.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: To the best of our knowledge, the present study is the first in the literature, which evaluates the relationship between the N:L ratio and SS in patients with STEMI. The main findings of this study are that (1) SS was independently correlated with N:L ratio in addition to DM, age, and EF and (2) the major increase in N:L ratio was observed in SShigh group.

Atherogenesis is an active, inflammatory process 1 with crucially acting functional/dysfunctional leukocytes. 18 Neutrophils play role either in adaptive infarct healing or in leukocyte platelet aggregate formation and in reperfusion injury in the setting of acute coronary syndromes. 19,20

Several previous studies have evaluated the association of total and differential WBC count and presence and prognosis of CAD. White blood cell count, neutrophil count, and N: L ratio were reported as an independent prognostic predictor both in acute MI 21
–24 and in stable CAD. 7 To elucidate the pathophysiological mechanism of elevated neutrophils, neutrophil invasion was either shown in atherosclerotic plaques of an animal model 25 or in the culprit clinical plaques of patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS) 26 besides the well-known neutrophilic infiltration of infarct zone that ultimately leads to fibrotic scar formation. Neutrophils not only promote fibrosis but also induce myocardial ischemia/infarction by assisting plaque disruption and by plugging of microvessels by coaggregating with platelets. 19,27
–30

Lymphocytes also play a crucial role in modulating the inflammatory response in atherosclerotic process 31 and comparative lymphopenia in MI was postulated as a stress response mediated by increased endogenous cortisol, 32,33 whereas decreased CD4 lymphocyte subset was reported to be associated with increased cardiovascular events in renal transplant recipients. 31

Our findings support previous studies on the association of differential WBC counts and the presence and prognosis of cardiovascular diseases. 34 Increase in the severity of CAD with respect to SS was associated with increased neutrophils and decreased lymphocytes in our study and ultimately with increased N:L ratio. Similar to the current study, a relationship between N:L ratio and severity of CAD was reported in patients with stable CAD. 6,7 However, a similar independent relationship was not investigated in STEMI. Horne et al 6 revealed high N or low L count as better independent predictor of death/MI in patients with or at high risk of CAD than total WBC count, whereas Papa et al 7 reported that the N:L ratio was an independent predictor of cardiac death in angiographically proven patients with CAD. A stronger association between the N:L ratio and SS compared with the relationship between SS and WBC count in the present study in patients with acute STEMI supports recent literature revealing that the N:L ratio was a more important parameter than total WBC count with regard to the presence, severity, and extent of stable coronary atherosclerosis. 6,7 Further prospective studies assessing the predictive role of both SS and N:L ratio in conjunction for risk stratification might improve risk prediction in patients with STEMI.

Avramakis et al 35 reported the changes in platelets and WBC subpopulations among patients with acute coronary syndrome (86 with AMI and 81 unstable angina pectoris) and controls (n = 83). They reported that patients with AMI had significantly lower platelet counts and eosinophil percentages compared with the controls. In our study, we studied only patients with STEMI and found that when SS was increased, both platelet and eosinophil counts tended to decrease. These changes may be markers of extent of myocardial damage. Differences in results may be attributed to factors such as patient characteristics and variations in treatment.

Previous studies have revealed serum UA as an independent predictor of mortality in patients with CAD 36 and predictor of in-hospital mortality in patients with STEMI. 37 Gur et al 38 reported that serum UA was associated with the presence of CAD but not with the severity of CAD, in patients undergoing coronary angiography. A previous meta-analysis did not find any association between UA levels and cardiovascular events. 39 Recently, Duran et al 40 reported that UA was associated with the severity of CAD with no information on WBC count and its subtypes such as neutrophil and lymphocytes. The present study is consistent with pertinent literature revealing controversial results on the relationship between UA and CAD as UA was related to the severity of CAD in bivariate analysis but not in multiple linear regression analysis in 840 patients with STEMI in our study.

In conclusion, the N:L ratio was independently associated with the severity of CAD in patients with STEMI. However, UA was not independently associated with the severity of CAD in patients with STEMI.
